company.name: VTech Electronics Limited and VTech Electronics North America, LLC
company.incorporation_state: Hong Kong (VTech Electronics Limited); Delaware (VTech Electronics North America, LLC)
company.address: Hong Kong (VTech Electronics Limited); Arlington Heights, Illinois (VTech Electronics North America, LLC)
company.business_description: VTech develops and markets electronic learning products (ELPs) for children ages 3-9, online games, and operates the Learning Lodge Navigator online service platform. The company also developed Kid Connect, a communication app for children, and Planet VTech, a web-based platform for online games and chat.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (15 U.S.C. § 45(a)); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d)); Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (16 C.F.R. Part 312)

complaint.factual_background: VTech Electronics Limited and VTech Electronics North America, LLC developed and operated children's electronic learning products and online services, including Learning Lodge Navigator, Kid Connect, and Planet VTech. These services collected personal information from children under 13 — including names, birthdates, photos, and audio files — without providing adequate privacy notices, without obtaining verifiable parental consent, and without maintaining reasonable data security. In November 2015, a hacker exploited well-known vulnerabilities to access VTech's network, traversing from the test environment to the live environment and exfiltrating personal information stored in clear text for millions of parents and children. VTech's Privacy Policy falsely claimed that personally identifying information submitted through its Web Services would be transmitted using HTTPS encryption, when in fact no registration information was encrypted in transmission or storage for Learning Lodge or Planet VTech.

representations_made.description: Claimed that most personally identifying information submitted through its Web Services would be transmitted encrypted using HTTPS encryption technology, and that any Registration Data submitted with encrypted PII would also be transmitted encrypted
representations_made.quoted_text: In most cases, if you submit your PII to VTech directly through the Web Services it will be transmitted encrypted to protect your privacy using HTTPS encryption technology. Any Registration Data submitted in conjunction with encrypted PII will also be transmitted encrypted.

counts.title: COPPA Rule Violations (Kid Connect)
counts.representation: Defendants collected personal information from children under 13 through Kid Connect, an online service directed to children, with actual knowledge that children used these services (evidenced by collecting birth dates and birth years)
counts.fact: Defendants failed to: (a) provide sufficient notice of their information collection practices on the website or online service; (b) provide direct notice to parents of information collection and use practices; (c) obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting or using personal information from children; and (d) establish and maintain reasonable procedures to protect the confidentiality, security, and integrity of personal information collected from children
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendants have violated the COPPA Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312, which constitutes an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

counts.title: False Encryption Representation (FTC Act Section 5)
counts.representation: Through their Privacy Policy applicable to Learning Lodge, Kid Connect, and Planet VTech, Defendants represented that most personally identifying information submitted by consumers and all registration information transmitted with it would be transmitted in encrypted form using HTTPS encryption technology
counts.fact: In truth and in fact, Defendants did not encrypt any information transmitted through their Learning Lodge or Planet VTech online services, including registration information
counts.conclusion: Therefore, Defendants' representation is false and misleading and constitutes a deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a).

definitions.Child: an individual under the age of 13.
definitions.Collects or collection: for the purposes of Parts I and VIII of this Order only, the gathering of any personal information from a child by any means, including but not limited to: 1. Requesting, prompting, or encouraging a child to submit personal information online; 2. Enabling a child to make personal information publicly available in identifiable form; or 3. Passive tracking of a child online.
definitions.Covered information: (1) registration information, and (2) personal information collected from a child.
definitions.Defendants: VTech Electronics Limited and VTech Electronics North America, LLC, and their successors and assigns, to the extent any of these entities market products or services to consumers in the United States.
definitions.Disclose or disclosure: with respect to personal information: 1. The release of personal information collected by an operator from a child in identifiable form for any purpose, except where an operator provides such information to a person who provides support for the internal operations of the Web site or online service; and 2. Making personal information collected by an operator from a child publicly available in identifiable form by any means, including but not limited to a public posting through the Internet, or through a personal home page or screen posted on a Web site or online service; a pen pal service; an electronic mail service; a message board; or a chat room.
definitions.Internet: collectively the myriad of computer and telecommunication facilities, including equipment and operating software, which comprises the interconnected world-wide network of networks that employ the Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol, or any predecessor or successor protocols to such protocol, to communicate information of all kinds by wire, radio, or other methods of transmission.
definitions.Obtaining verifiable consent: making any reasonable effort (taking into consideration available technology) to ensure that before personal information is collected from a child, a parent of the child: 1. Receives notice of the operator's personal information collection, use, and disclosure practices; and 2. Authorizes any collection, use, and/or disclosure of the personal information.
definitions.Online contact information: an email address or any other substantially similar identifier that permits direct contact with a person online, including but not limited to, an instant messaging user identifier, a voice over internet protocol (VOIP) identifier, or a video chat identifier.
definitions.Operator: any person who operates a Web site located on the Internet or an online service and who collects or maintains personal information from or about the users of or visitors to such Web site or online service, or on whose behalf such information is collected or maintained, or offers products or services for sale through the Web site or online service, where such Web site or online service is operated for commercial purposes involving commerce among the several States, or with one or more foreign nations; in any territory of the United States or in the District of Columbia, or between any such territory and another such territory or any State or foreign nation; or between the District of Columbia and any State, territory, or foreign nation.
definitions.Person: any individual, partnership, corporation, trust, estate, cooperative, association, or other entity.
definitions.Registration information: information collected by Defendants from individual consumers in the course of registering to use Defendants' products or services, including: 1. A first and last name; 2. A home or other physical address including street name and name of a city or town; 3. Online contact information; 4. A telephone number; 5. A Social Security number; 6. Authentication credentials, such as a username and password; 7. Photo, video, or audio files; and 8. The name, date of birth, and any personal information relating to a child.
definitions.Support for the internal operations of t: 1. Those activities necessary to: a. Maintain or analyze the functioning of the Web site or online service; b. Perform network communications; c. Authenticate users of, or personalize the content on, the Web site or online service; d. Serve contextual advertising on the Web site or online service or cap the frequency of advertising; e. Protect the security or integrity of the user, Web site, or online service; f. Ensure legal or regulatory compliance; or g. Fulfill a request of a child as permitted by 16 C.F.R. §§ 312.5(c)(3) and (4); 2. So long as the information collected for the activities listed in paragraphs (1)(a)-(g) of this definition is not used or disclosed to contact a specific individual, including through behavioral advertising, to amass a profile on a specific individual, or for any other purpose.
definitions.Web site or online service directed to c: a commercial Web site or online service, or portion thereof, that is targeted to children.

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning the Collection of Personal Information (COPPA Compliance)
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting with them are permanently restrained from violating the COPPA Rule, including failing to provide direct parental notice, failing to post a privacy policy link, failing to obtain verifiable parental consent, and failing to maintain reasonable security procedures.
